item.title: How the Supreme Court Unleashed Trump’s War on the States
item.description: The Trump administration's militarization of US cities – apparently selected because of their partisan divergence from the White House – represents a failure of federalism. While Congress's abdication of its constitutional duties is well known, the Supreme Court has joined it in greenlighting executive overreach.

item.title: Can Ethical Supply Chains Survive the Tariff Storm?
item.description: As trade-related costs persist, fashion and apparel industry leaders must shift their mindset. Their businesses’ resilience will not come from diplomacy or presidential handshakes, but from trust-based relationships built on fair purchasing practices, sustainability concerns, and other ethical commitments.

item.title: How Much Financial Speculation Can the Real Economy Withstand?
item.description: Fueled by mobile-trading apps, deregulation, and social media, short-term speculation is reshaping financial markets and eroding the patient capital on which businesses have long relied. If left unchecked, this frenzy could destabilize the US economy and set the stage for a 2008-style global crisis.

item.title: As Growth Decouples From Employment, the Fed Faces a Trilemma
item.description: With equity markets reaching new heights, the market’s expectation that the US Federal Reserve will cut rates to head off a labor-market slowdown is itself creating a policy challenge for the central bank. In addition to its explicit dual mandate, the Fed now must also worry about financial stability.

item.title: How the Democrats Can “Win” the US Government Shutdown
item.description: To prevail against a would-be autocrat, US Democrats should make an argument about democracy. Not only has a Republican-controlled government closed, but the Republican-controlled Congress is simply handing power to an executive who has signaled clearly his intention to act illegally and unconstitutionally.

item.title: What Mayors Need to Lead
item.description: As power in the United Kingdom continues to shift from London to the rest of the country, and as the European Union looks to city governments to drive an economic recovery and more, people across the continent will increasingly be counting on local leaders. The task now is to make sure those leaders are equipped for the task.

item.title: India’s Strategic Balancing Act
item.description: Strategic autonomy is not about oscillating between poles, but about preventing one's own agenda from being subsumed by that of another power. For India today, this means preventing escalation with China without succumbing to the illusion of partnership, and negotiating firmly with the US without disrupting constructive engagement.

item.title: Africa’s Rare-Earth Opportunity
item.description: As global demand for critical minerals surges, Africa has a once-in-a-century opportunity to break the “resource curse” and convert its vast natural wealth into economic and social transformation. But, to seize it, the continent’s leaders must avoid falling into old traps.

item.title: The UN Without America
item.description: Though multilateralism remains as important as ever to defend human rights, support peace and security, and deliver cooperative solutions to shared problems, the 80th session of the United Nations General Assembly painted a bleak picture of the institution’s prospects. To avoid fading into irrelevance, the UN must transform itself – including by radically reducing its dependence on the United States.

item.title: The Big Picture
What’s Next for Multilateralism?
item.description: On the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly, thousands of leaders from civil society, business, educational institutions, and philanthropies discussed how the world can conduct diplomacy without the US. To that end, middle powers must convene the UNGA elsewhere and increase their accountability to the global community.

item.title: The Case for Gradual Population Decline
item.description: Contrary to conventional wisdom, rapid population growth rarely delivers demographic dividends, while low fertility rates do not necessarily lead to stagnation. In fact, persistently high fertility often exacerbates underemployment, limits investment in education and infrastructure, and entrenches poverty across generations.

item.title: Kazakhstan’s Digital Crossroad
item.description: To reduce its reliance on Russia’s internet ecosystem, Kazakhstan has invested significant sums in upgrading its infrastructure and developing international transit capabilities. But becoming a digital hub will ultimately depend on whether the government loosens its regulatory hold on the internet.

item.title: Must Our Globalized World Be a Suicide Pact?
item.description: Silicon Valley pitchmen would like us to believe that technology will determine the future. But the more important variable is whether and how our institutions adapt, a matter that remains entirely within our power to decide – at least for now.

item.title: Latin America’s Structural Crisis
item.description: Decades of sluggish growth, premature deindustrialization, and insufficient investment have left Latin American countries dependent on commodity exports and vulnerable to external shocks. To avoid another lost decade, governments must adopt bold industrial policies, deepen regional integration, and focus on job creation.

item.title: The Making or Breaking of Democracy
item.description: The rise of authoritarian leaders like US President Donald Trump shows that too many of us took democracy, and the prosperity it generates, for granted. Now, a growing movement of democratic countries is coming together to push back on the dangerous trend that Trump represents.

item.title: Mexico Must End Cash Dependence
item.description: Mexico’s cash-heavy economy leaves it vulnerable to tax evasion, corruption, and money laundering. By emulating successful electronic-payment platforms in emerging markets like Brazil and India, policymakers could foster financial inclusion, boost government revenues, and stabilize public finances.

item.title: Science Needs a New Social Compact
item.description: For decades, the American research university underpinned US progress in science, and that progress established the country as a global leader in innovation. But the old model of incentivizing, funding, and commercializing scientific discovery rested on some core assumptions that no longer hold.

item.title: Trump Is Losing His Geoeconomic War
item.description: In seeking to weaponize the US economy and financial system against China, Russia, and many other countries, Donald Trump has picked a fight that he cannot win. After all, it is much easier for other countries to develop alternatives to the dollar than for America suddenly to develop its own rare earths industry.

item.title: Restoring Public-Sector Capacity Where It Counts
item.description: Cities are where tomorrow’s opportunities will be seized and where today’s crises, from climate change to inequality, hit hardest. Strengthening city governments is therefore a strategic imperative that requires significant investment, sustained coordination, and continuous learning.
